title: Famous Faces
description: Can you identify these famous people from their descriptions? Test your memory of iconic figures!

questions.question: Which famous person is known for their iconic white dress blowing up over a subway grate in the 1955 film 'The Seven Year Itch'?
questions.explanation: Marilyn Monroe's white halter dress scene became one of the most iconic images in cinema history.

questions.question: Which famous scientist is known for his wild white hair, theory of relativity, and the equation E=mcÂ²?
questions.explanation: Albert Einstein's distinctive appearance and groundbreaking physics made him the most recognizable scientist in history.

questions.question: Which monarch reigned for over 70 years, was crowned in 1953, and was known for her colorful matching outfits and handbags?
questions.explanation: Queen Elizabeth II became the longest-reigning British monarch, serving from 1952 until her death in 2022.

questions.question: Which U.S. President is remembered for his tall stovepipe hat, beard, and delivering the Gettysburg Address?
questions.explanation: Abraham Lincoln's towering height of 6'4" and distinctive top hat made him instantly recognizable. He led the nation through the Civil War.

questions.question: Which actress is remembered for her role as Holly Golightly in 'Breakfast at Tiffany's,' often pictured in a little black dress and pearls?
questions.explanation: Audrey Hepburn became a fashion icon and beloved actress, also known for her humanitarian work with UNICEF.

questions.question: Which silent film star is known for his 'Little Tramp' character, bowler hat, small mustache, baggy pants, and cane?
questions.explanation: Charlie Chaplin's 'Little Tramp' character became one of the most recognized images in film history during the silent era.

questions.question: Which civil rights leader is famous for his 'I Have a Dream' speech delivered at the Lincoln Memorial in 1963?
questions.explanation: Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his iconic speech during the March on Washington, becoming a defining moment of the civil rights movement.

questions.question: Which member of the British royal family was known as 'The People's Princess' and was famous for her humanitarian work and her iconic sapphire engagement ring?
questions.explanation: Princess Diana captured the world's heart with her compassion and style. Her sapphire ring later became Kate Middleton's engagement ring.

questions.question: Which rock and roll legend was known as 'The King,' famous for his hip-swiveling dance moves and living at Graceland in Memphis?
questions.explanation: Elvis Presley revolutionized popular music and became one of the most significant cultural icons of the 20th century.

questions.question: Which British Prime Minister is known for his 'V for Victory' hand sign, ever-present cigar, and leading Britain through World War II?
questions.explanation: Winston Churchill's defiant leadership and rousing speeches rallied the British people during their darkest hours in WWII.

questions.question: Which Mexican artist is famous for her vibrant self-portraits, unibrow, floral headpieces, and paintings that explored identity and pain?
questions.explanation: Frida Kahlo created deeply personal artwork influenced by Mexican folk art. Her distinctive appearance became iconic worldwide.

questions.question: Which U.S. President, known for his youthful charm and the Camelot era, gave the famous 'Ich bin ein Berliner' speech in 1963?
questions.explanation: John F. Kennedy was the 35th U.S. President. His presidency and tragic assassination in 1963 remain defining moments in American history.

questions.question: Which Nobel Peace Prize winner is known for wearing a white sari with blue trim and founding the Missionaries of Charity in Calcutta?
questions.explanation: Mother Teresa dedicated her life to serving the poorest of the poor in India and was canonized as a saint in 2016.

questions.question: Which entertainment pioneer created a beloved cartoon mouse, built a famous theme park in California, and won 22 Academy Awards?
questions.explanation: Walt Disney created Mickey Mouse in 1928 and opened Disneyland in 1955. He holds the record for the most Academy Awards won by an individual.

questions.question: Which astronaut is famous for saying 'That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind' when becoming the first person to walk on the Moon?
questions.explanation: Neil Armstrong made history on July 20, 1969, when he became the first human to set foot on the Moon during the Apollo 11 mission.
